awd_abstract_narration:
The Florida-Georgia LSAMP (FGLSAMP) is seeking to continue to employ its current program model while enhancing and focusing upon critical junctures for successful matriculation through the STEM academic pipeline. Given its mission to significantly increase the number of baccalaureate degrees awarded to underrepresented minorities in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics FGLSAMP will focus greater attention on utilizing effective models and best practices for expanding the pipeline of community college students matriculating into STEM disciplines at the university level. In conjunction with the emphasis on community college students, two additional areas of focus include expanding participation in international research experiences and enhancing means of growing the number of students entering STEM PhD programs. These additions to FGLSAMP will enable FGLSAMP to build upon its successful track record and will allow FGLSAMP to achieve its goals for 2012-2017.

FGLSAMP proposes to significantly expand its STEM talent pool through greater collaboration among the 14 partner institutions and enhanced practices that result in: 1) student retention and graduation in STEM disciplines; 2) effectively preparing and matriculating FGLSAMP community college students to pursue baccalaureate degrees in STEM disciplines; 3) providing significant STEM international research opportunities 4) preparation of FGLSAMP undergraduate participants for STEM graduate education opportunities. FGLSAMP will augment its current STEM socialization practices to achieve these key guide posts, which are at the heart of all FGLSAMP academic enhancement and professional development activities.

The targeted metrics for our five-year program period also include:
-	Expand the talent pool of institutional underrepresented minorities awarded STEM undergraduate and graduate degrees by 15% annually (2,247 baseline) 
-	Place at least 75% percent of FGLSAMP B.S. degree recipients into STEM graduate programs 
-	Maintain a STEM retention rate of greater than 80% among FGLSAMP undergraduates at ASU, BCU, FAMU and FIU
-	Achieve 5 year time-to-graduation rate of 85% 
-	Place more than 20 annually students into international research programs by 2014
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The FGLSAMP model is largely focused upon addressing and diminishing STEM attritition among historically underrepresented minorities pursuing undergraduate degrees iin STEM disciplines. Creating holistic earning communities for students whereby students are embraced, affirmed, and supported along their undergraduate journey. At FGLSAMP Institutions, ASU, BCU, FAMU, MDC, UF and TCC have a significant focus on community service from tutoring/mentoring in K-12 and collegiate peers, community service and engagement projects. It is evidenced that student engagement in these types of activities are significant to diminishing the sense of isolation that students feel in STEM majors as well as the overall college experience.   

FGLSAMP has played a vital role in developing historically underrepresented minority students who are prepared to make significant contributions in STEM careers. The broader impact of the alliance is that it has produced and utilized a program model is effective in the retention and graduation of students in STEM disciplines. The alliance has maintained a an effective retention rate of 88% along with a STEM graduation rate of 89% among student participants. FGLSAMP students enrolling in STEM graduate programs reamins around 40%, an area we seek to grow in the future. 

The FGLSAMP approach to student development is comprised of immersive STEM experiences that support or enhance classroom learning. Students are encourage and prepared to attend professional activities such as research conference or symposia events as a means to expand their intellectual pursuits and heighten their cultural exposure and sensitivity.

Having found that early engagement in research experiences to be a leading factor in student retention, FGLSAMP has One of the primary factors for retention. Of the approximately 265 students supported annually, 70% engaged in research either during the academic year and/or during the summer. The percentage at the predominantly undergraduate institutions within the alliance the research internships percentages were: ASU 78%; BCU 70%; FIU 78%; and FAMU 74%. There have been 12 alliance students who've participated in international research experiences.

FGLSAMP community college partner Tallahassee Community College had 9 student participate in research at Brookhaven National Laboratory. In addition, Miami dade College (2yr inst.) had more than 10 students oarticipate in research with the USDA. FGLSAMP has had 5 coomunity college students to successfully matriculate into Ph.D programs. Recently one FGLSAMP alum who started at the community college level was featured in Forbes magazine  about his company Sensatek (ceramic sensors) in the aerospace industry. 

Annually more than 110 FGLSAMP students throughout the alliance participated in research and professional conferences, most notably the ABRCMS, SACNAS, NoBche, and the NSF-ERN conference whereby students presented their research and engaged in networking opportunities for research internshiips, graduate school, and career. FGLSAMP students also attended regional confernce such as the Peach State LSAMP conference and the Florida Undergraduate Research Confernce. Conference participation is a significant component of professional development.

To better prepare students for future careers in STEM professions, FGLSAMP developed a Computational and Data Enabled Science initiative that was implemented on a virtual platform and largely student activated learning model. The virtues of this initiative was evidenced during the proliferation of COVID-19. FGLSAMP facilitated student research and learning activities by conductng virtual research activities that focused students investigations of large scale inquiries related to social determinants of COVID-19; learning coding for researching this phenomenon using Python and R, and the utilization of artificial intelliegence, machine learning, and data science application as research tools. FGLSAMP also partnered with Brookhaven National Lab and Indiana Unviersity to facilitate cyber based research investigations and learning. These experiences have greatly elevated student learning, performance, and technical competencies for working in virtual research environments with team members located in different geographical locations, as well as from divers backgrounds. This initiative has hosted 105 students participants. FGLSAMP also began a Thought Leaders Speaker Series which allows students to engage with researchers and STEM professionals through a virtual platform. This presenters are from academia, research laboratories, and insudtry. It is a part of our on-going professional development effort. 

FGLSAMP continues to learn and adapt to new approaches to create education and traiining  experiences to cultivate successful outcome for its student participants.  

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2022
Modified by: Richard A Alo
